comment.body:
> [kaffie](#comment_4_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): The issue is having sloppy indexes and results. I'm providing what I see to be a quality service. If that improves the overall search environment of ZeroNet, then mission accomplished.

In the end, quality will come out over quantity. 
I have no doubts that Kaffiene will continue to attract lots of users, as long as you keep it the way you do now.
Of course, posting big numbers looks good - but when getting duplicate results, I personally look for the search engine that has the least redundancies and works the best.

Hey, there you go! I really like the new interface, it looks familiar (even though I haven't been using Google for a long while, now) and feels right, especially with the tag highlighting and the fancier, but still minimal enough buttons. 

As for having a "smaller" index than ZeroSearch, I wouldn't worry too much about that. Quality over quality, definitely and as soon as you manage to work on a crawler that feeds into Kaffiene,  you will have  a definite advantage over the competition, even if they boast big numbers. 

A problem that some users may encounter, though, is not knowing that the checkbox next to the search bar is used for enabling clickable tags, you may want to give a small hint on that somewhere.

As always, I like the way Kaffiene is taking and what is continuing to happen with the competition between Kaffiene and the other search engines (with a glaring exception).

This is mostly healthy competition, and sharing is definitely key in such a transparent system as ZeroNet is.
